description: Interactive software package for PCR primer design. PRISE enables the design of sequence-specific / sequence-selective PCR primers. One important feature of PRISE is that it automates the task of placing primer-template mismatches at the 3′ end of the primers – a property that is crucial for sequence selectivity / specificity.
name: PRISE

metadata.abstract: This report presents PRImer Selector (PRISE), a new software package that implements several features that improve and streamline the design of sequence-selective PCR primers. The PRISE design process involves two main steps. In the first step, target and non-target DNA sequences are identified. In the second step, primers are designed to amplify target (but not non-target) sequences. One important feature of PRISE is that it automates the task of placing primer-template mismatches at the 3' end of the primers - a property that is crucial for sequence selectivity. Once a list of candidate primers has been produced, sorting tools in PRISE speed up the selection process by allowing a user to sort the primers by properties such as amplicon length, GC content and sequence selectivity. PRISE can be used to design primers with a range of specificities, targeting individual sequences as well as diverse assemblages of genes. PRISE also allows user-defined primers to be analyzed, enabling their properties to be examined in relation to target and non-target sequences. The utility of PRISE was demonstrated by using it to design sequence-selective PCR primers for an rRNA gene from the fungus Pochonia chlamydosporia. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.title: PRISE (PRImer SElector): Software for designing sequence-selective PCR primers
